summary: Daniel K. Inouye is mentioned in the context of the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) and the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence (SSCI) inquiries into the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. While the documents do not explicitly detail Inouye's direct involvement, his presence is implied through the SSCI's investigations into Cuban intelligence networks and related materials held by the NSA. The documents reference the SSCI's request for information on individuals like Antonio Veciana and related Cuban matters, indicating Inouye's potential role as a member of the committee overseeing these investigations. The timeline of his involvement is generally situated around the mid-to-late 1970s, coinciding with the HSCA and SSCI investigations.
significance: Daniel K. Inouye's significance in the JFK context stems from his potential role as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence (SSCI), which was involved in investigating the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The SSCI's inquiries into Cuban intelligence networks and related materials suggest Inouye's indirect involvement in the investigation, although the specific details of his contributions are not explicitly outlined in the provided documents.
